summary: Inflammatory breast cancer (IBC) is a rare and aggressive type of breast cancer characterized by cancer cells blocking lymph vessels in the skin of the breast, leading to a warm, red, and swollen appearance. It often presents without detectable lumps and can mimic skin inflammation like mastitis. IBC is typically diagnosed at a later stage and has a poorer prognosis than other breast cancers, though recent advances in therapy have improved survival rates.
causes: Invasion of the local lymphatic ducts
risk_factors: Radiation therapy to the breast or chest
symptoms: Unusually warm skin of the breast
Peau d'orange (dimpled appearance of breast skin)
Swelling of lymph nodes under the arm or in the neck
Breast size may seem to decrease
diagnosis: Biopsy of suspected lesions and/or skin
Genetic tests for BRCA and TP53 genes
